guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

parent.body:
Mary has been the Queen of Heaven for virtually every Christian from the 3rd Century AD (quite possibly earlier) until the Reformation, and she still is for every Christian except the Reformed. Sophia predates the Gnostics by many hundreds of years and most likely well into early Christianity. The Gnostics expanded her, but they did not create her, she just fell out of fashion in Orthodox circles early on.


Asherah was still a part of Ancient Israel long after the rest of the gods were done away with, only a couple hundred years removed from Sophia, and associated with the same symbols. So it's either the same character or a natural synchronic re-emergence, as there was with Sophia and Mary.

Asherah is never never particularly admonished by the prophets alongside the others, except Jeremiah, but Jeremiah manuscripts are ones most scholars agree have been extensively edited, and even still, it comes up in like one chapter. Jeremiah tells them to knock it off, Israel tells him no, because when they make things for the Queen of Heaven, they were blessed, which was true. But Jeremiah said he was going to tell Dad (Yahweh) and they would totally get smitten (they weren't.) The whole thing reads like propaganda, almost as transparently as the Books of Kings, which were clearly written near the end of the history, telling the narrative from the perspective of radical reformers.


It can be interpreted metaphorically, and it usually is retrospectively. But it wasn't meant to be a metaphor when it was written, Wisdom was man's advocate against Yahweh's jealous wrath. This revisionism is similar to how God's tempter in the Book of Job becomes the personification of evil in Christianity and late 2nd Temple Judaism. You admit certain details in the Gospels do this for the virgin birth, but the case for the feminine presentation of God is actually a lot stronger.

Whether you want to acknowledge it as legitimate religion or not, though, can be somewhat ignored. There absolutely is a through-line of a feminine person of God as far back as we can trace. Asherah was with Israel as far back as we know (between 2,000-4,000 BC) when she goes away, most likely under King Josiah's Reformation, she's just "replaced" with Sophia a couple hundred years later, not even long enough for memory of Asherah to go away. Then Sophia is replaced by Mary a couple hundred years after that. They are all one, and have been extant from the beginning. Protestantism is the first movement ever in this entire tradition that has successfully gotten rid of it for so long.

body:
Your last paragraph pretty much proves my point. If Sophia is God's spirit, then she's a concept, and they're the same entity. God has different aspects of him described in multiple ways. How it got misrepresented afterward as two separate gods isn't hard to fathom considering the pagan-infested days of Israel and Judah. They also wouldn't have been comfortable with feminine aspects of God considering how wives were literally purchased in the ancient world, so I'm sure a lot of them liked assigning it all to "God's wife" instead. And considering how marriage doesn't even exist in the new world, nor ever among angels and spiritual beings (except Nephilim)--and according to the ancient understanding probably not gender either--it's a bit of a stretch to think God is a literal man married to a literal goddess. That's more of a pagan idea, and paganism itself probably stems from these kinds of misrepresentations of the one god. It's easy to see how monotheistic metaphors for an omnisicient entity could become corrupted over the generations into stories about literal god people in the sky who are just magical humans, but that being the original story and taken seriously is outlandish.

Mary was merely a biological parent who birthed Jesus. A normal human. And considering the evidence, probably with Joseph's seed. God is always his spiritual father, not his biological one, despite how much people struggle with this concept.

parent.body:
Jesus is the sacrificial God-man, he certainly encompasses wisdom. But foremost, he is the Son, you can think of him as a meta soldier. The son goes to war to save the tribe (or nation, whatever) in wartime and will often have to lay down his life. Christ did it without a physical war ever taking place. The parallel is quite striking, and I think the correct way of looking at it, he gave his life to end a war of the spirit.

Jesus is also the logos. Which... isn't actually that clear, or even agreed on between different sects. It's usually translated as "The Word" but it has a lot of meanings. Plea, or proportion, or expectation. By the 7th century it approximately meant "knowledge" but not at the time of writing. Most contemporary Christians say it means he is the "Word of God" but I don't think that expression was ever used.

I think the Word is a good translation though. I think the statement means that Jesus is God, and co-eternal with God, and the beginning of God was the Word, or the beginning of spoken language.

I think what you're probably getting at, though, is prayer, right? Well, we know a good starting point might be to follow Baptismal practice. To do so in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Spirit. I don't pray to Sophia or Mary. I wasn't raised Roman Catholic, it seems like an inconvenience. But I don't personally pray "to" anyone. My personal prayer cues are largely inspired by the Greek Church. My prayer is a silent meditation, and in that meditation, answers to problems will emerge, almost without exception.

But I can go a bit farther with it. I think, while Sophia's incarnation, so to speak, is the Holy Mother, her presence is the same as the Holy Spirit. Going by traditional gender assignments, the Holy Spirit is external and exploratory, so it is a female concept. More definitively female than the Gnostic Sophia, anyway. She accidentally created everything masculine in the physical world.

> It's really important to note that Israel was historically polytheistic first, that's the story archaeology tells.

Because they were so full of idolatry and false gods.

> The allusions to a polytheism are still largely in the Psalms, it speaks of a council of Gods and battles with the Leviathan, and all manner or things. It's a lot easier to revise history than it is poetry.

Poetry is also exactly where you would expect metaphorical concepts to show up. We also don't know the authenticity of each Psalm.

> Gendering concepts is a cross-cultural phenomenon. The idea of the co-eternal Sophia goes back to the Book of Proverbs. I don't think it's a separate entity, though, I think Sophia is a different presentation of God, a Divine Principle made conscious, just like the Father and the Son. Because God is the Divine Ideal, or the Archetype, and the ideal archetype is not necessarily the same between the older and the younger, the man and the woman, etc. so even a monotheistic God may have different presentations.

That's what I was trying to say. Which refutes your first point claiming that gender exists because there is a separate male and female god:

> Traditionally, Yahweh himself had a feminine part in Sophia, or his Asherah. The precise name and relationship of it changes depending on which era you're looking at, but her core attribute is always wisdom. If your Bible has the Deuterocanon, you'll see a recurring motif in the extended wisdom literature; that is the personification of Wisdom as a woman. (This role was transfigured into Mary in the early Christian traditions.)
body_html:
It's really important to note that Israel was historically polytheistic first, that's the story archaeology tells.

Because they were so full of idolatry and false gods.

The allusions to a polytheism are still largely in the Psalms, it speaks of a council of Gods and battles with the Leviathan, and all manner or things. It's a lot easier to revise history than it is poetry.

Poetry is also exactly where you would expect metaphorical concepts to show up. We also don't know the authenticity of each Psalm.

Gendering concepts is a cross-cultural phenomenon. The idea of the co-eternal Sophia goes back to the Book of Proverbs. I don't think it's a separate entity, though, I think Sophia is a different presentation of God, a Divine Principle made conscious, just like the Father and the Son. Because God is the Divine Ideal, or the Archetype, and the ideal archetype is not necessarily the same between the older and the younger, the man and the woman, etc. so even a monotheistic God may have different presentations.

That's what I was trying to say. Which refutes your first point claiming that gender exists because there is a separate male and female god:

Traditionally, Yahweh himself had a feminine part in Sophia, or his Asherah. The precise name and relationship of it changes depending on which era you're looking at, but her core attribute is always wisdom. If your Bible has the Deuterocanon, you'll see a recurring motif in the extended wisdom literature; that is the personification of Wisdom as a woman. (This role was transfigured into Mary in the early Christian traditions.)

parent.body:
>How it got misrepresented afterward as two separate gods isn't hard to fathom considering the pagan-infested days of Israel and Judah.

It's really important to note that Israel was historically polytheistic first, that's the story archaeology tells. It's not the one the Deuteronomist tells, but that was written near the end of the Kingdom, so we can't necessarily trust it as an infallible history. The allusions to a polytheism are still largely in the Psalms, it speaks of a council of Gods and battles with the Leviathan, and all manner or things. It's a lot easier to revise history than it is poetry.

>it's a bit of a stretch to think God is a literal man married to a literal goddess.

Gendering concepts is a cross-cultural phenomenon. The idea of the co-eternal Sophia goes back to the Book of Proverbs. I don't think it's a separate entity, though, I think Sophia is a different presentation of God, a Divine Principle made conscious, just like the Father and the Son. Because God is the Divine Ideal, or the Archetype, and the ideal archetype is not necessarily the same between the older and the younger, the man and the woman, etc. so even a monotheistic God may have different presentations. It's also why the history of the Saints are important, they're a subset of this presentation made physical. We see a similar ideal being expressed in infinite varieties over time, and extract the meta, Christlike ideal from it.

I don't think there's a God named Yahweh and a God named Sophia hanging out in Heaven spending all their time engaged in spirit sex, I'm not a Mormon. I don't necessarily think Yahweh as he's presented in the Old Testament is the pure expression of whatever God is either, though it's the closest thing we have. I think God presents himself as El, or Yahweh, or the Father, and also presents himself as Sophia, who is the Holy Mother and advocate against Yahweh's jealous wrath, God is entirely both of these things, it's not polytheism.

Gnostics had an incorrect cosmology, but they were definitely onto something in separating the naive, stupid "gods" from the great immaterial, boundless God. It's a Platonic expression of Enlightenment philosophy over a thousand years prior to the Enlightenment. Absolutely revolutionary, and a realization I had about Sethianism in particular only recently.

post.body:
I think an hour long service needs to set aside time for the congregation for self-reflection and introspection - leave sometime for the individual to sort themselves with God.

Some Church services I have been to lately - I don't ever have time for myself.  When we pray, I'm told exactly what to pray by the worship leader.  There is never a moment's peace between the concert-like contemporary music and the charismatic ramblings of the preacher... 

I wonder if it is on purpose - I take these thing as a sign that the specific church is more attune to a cult of personality than to the teachings of Christ.

It may just be a matter of taste I suppose.

> I'd be lying if I said recent developments didn't seem like something pulled out of the first few chapters of a Left Behind novel.

Then again the majority of human history seems even more like that, so it's just the ways of the world I guess.

> I did see some commentary regarding the vaccine and the vaccine passports that indicate that at least some Christians believe the vaccination is "The Mark of the Beast." It's credible. Not being able to buy or sell. A mark on your wrist (QR Code bracelets) or forehead (not sure), the political statement of allegiance, etc...

An even more accurate match is the mark of allegiance to the Roman Emperor, particularly Nero whose name in Hebrew adds up to both 666 and 616 depending on the dialect. They couldn't outright state these kinds of things because of the Roman authorities, so they had to put it in a way only they would understand. But any kind of swearing allegiance to an earthly authority is just as dangerous, so if that's what the vaccine becomes then it is too.

> However, there are videos of people in India being forced to take it. One guy was on his roof. Another woman was protesting the idea while doctors held out her arm and forced her to take it. While this makes it even more strange, doesn't that disqualify it as being a "Mark of the Beast" candidate as it is no longer a matter of willingness?

Yes, because the mark of the beast was allegiance to Rome and the Roman Emperor. If you refused you'd be restricted and persecuted and killed, not forced to take it as its whole purpose was to test your loyalty.
body_html:
I'd be lying if I said recent developments didn't seem like something pulled out of the first few chapters of a Left Behind novel.

Then again the majority of human history seems even more like that, so it's just the ways of the world I guess.

I did see some commentary regarding the vaccine and the vaccine passports that indicate that at least some Christians believe the vaccination is "The Mark of the Beast." It's credible. Not being able to buy or sell. A mark on your wrist (QR Code bracelets) or forehead (not sure), the political statement of allegiance, etc...

An even more accurate match is the mark of allegiance to the Roman Emperor, particularly Nero whose name in Hebrew adds up to both 666 and 616 depending on the dialect. They couldn't outright state these kinds of things because of the Roman authorities, so they had to put it in a way only they would understand. But any kind of swearing allegiance to an earthly authority is just as dangerous, so if that's what the vaccine becomes then it is too.

However, there are videos of people in India being forced to take it. One guy was on his roof. Another woman was protesting the idea while doctors held out her arm and forced her to take it. While this makes it even more strange, doesn't that disqualify it as being a "Mark of the Beast" candidate as it is no longer a matter of willingness?

Yes, because the mark of the beast was allegiance to Rome and the Roman Emperor. If you refused you'd be restricted and persecuted and killed, not forced to take it as its whole purpose was to test your loyalty.

post.body:
For the sake of transparency, I don't know if I'd consider myself a Christian today. I'm not here to mock anyone or argue. I'm genuinely curious.

As somebody who read the Bible and was into the End Times prophecy stuff, I'd be lying if I said recent developments didn't seem like something pulled out of the first few chapters of a Left Behind novel. 

I did see some commentary regarding the vaccine and the vaccine passports that indicate that at least some Christians believe the vaccination is "The Mark of the Beast." It's credible. Not being able to buy or sell. A mark on your wrist (QR Code bracelets) or forehead (not sure), the political statement of allegiance, etc...

However, there are videos of people in India being forced to take it. One guy was on his roof. Another woman was protesting the idea while doctors held out her arm and forced her to take it. While this makes it even more strange, doesn't that disqualify it as being a "Mark of the Beast" candidate as it is no longer a matter of willingness?

body:
They were plucking grain on the Sabbath. I doubt they were just picking it off and eating it raw. Jesus's comment implies the original commandment was more about not making other people work more than 6 days a week.

And the Old Testament absolutely does condone judging and hating one's enemy in many instances. It's even infamous for it, especially the Pentateuch. Jesus however has ministry activities far outside of Jewish peoples into enemy territory, much to the dismay of the Pharisees and Sadducees who were too proud of their heritage. Judging by his actions he does not seems like someone who would say "love your enemy" but actually mean "you can still hate your enemy".

Jesus's golden rule directly contradicts much of both testaments. And I don't think it's a coincidence that those tend to be exactly the parts that seem like they were added later by some scribe.

parent.body:
“While the people of Israel were in the wilderness, they found a man gathering sticks on the Sabbath day. And those who found him gathering sticks brought him to Moses and Aaron and to all the congregation. They put him in custody, because it had not been made clear what should be done to him. And the Lord said to Moses, “The man shall be put to death; all the congregation shall stone him with stones outside the camp.” And all the congregation brought him outside the camp and stoned him to death with stones, as the Lord commanded Moses.”

The death penalty for violating the sabbath was originally set in Exodus 31:14,
“You shall keep the Sabbath, because it is holy for you. Everyone who profanes it shall be put to death. Whoever does any work on it, that soul shall be cut off from among his people.”

Granted, this could be what led the Pharisees into condemning picking up any item on the sabbath. However, the command for the Sabbath was not to work, and we can logically assume:

1. The man was not gathering sticks for no reason.
2. The man was not gathering sticks to prepare an offering, which is permitted in Numbers 28:9, and confirmed by Jesus in Matthew 12, and would ironically be considered to “profane” the sabbath by the Pharisees(“Or have you not read in the Law how on the Sabbath the priests in the temple profane the Sabbath and are guiltless?”)

The most rational conclusion would be that this man was gathering sticks in a work effort involving sticks, thereby deserving of his penalty. However, “work” does not mean getting out of bed in the morning, nor does it mean lifting up food to eat, such as Jesus were.

> "Man was not made for the Sabbath, but the Sabbath for man". This alone is a major contradiction. 

No? It’s a plainly true statement. Jesus acknowledges that Man was created, then the Sabbath was created as a day to cease working, in remembrance of God ceasing the creation of the universe on the seventh day. This is contradictory to the Pharisees’ idea that Man cannot be healed on the Sabbath, despite it not being work. It’s only a “major contradiction” if you distort the idea of the Sabbath.

> The Pharisees were following the prescription just as it was written in their time. 
No. We see, by the Matthew 12 example, that they followed a misinterpretation of the sabbath.

> When you try to reconcile so many contradicting ideas you end up with things like Marcionism, or like most of modern Christendom picking and choosing the parts that align with the preferred theology and ignoring those that don't.

When you try to reconcile all contradictory ideas, it would end up with things like Marcionism. If we instead review each idea and it’s individual merit, while accepting that, upon review, most interpretations simply don’t hold water, such as God condemning animal sacrifice, we do not end up with things like Marcionism. If we were to have two historical accounts,
John entered the code 3815 to the safe at 11:00 pm. It opened. He closed it.
John entered the code 2815 to the safe at 11:03 pm. It didn’t open.

Interpretations:
“It was the wrong code.”
“The safe is racist.”
“The first historical account is fake.”
“The safe isn’t real.”
“They are different Johns”

If I were to say, “Alright, the safe is a racist and nonexistant. The first account is fake, and between the first and second account are different Johns. Also, it was the wrong code,” I wouldn’t be taken seriously.
If I were to say, “Alright, the safe can’t be racist and nonexistant at the same time, the first historical account is fake,” I could be taken even less seriously. 
With the information we have, we can say “It was the wrong code,” is the interpretation we should follow.

> The typical excuse for doing this is called dispensationalism, where Jesus apparently "fulfilled the law, well at least the parts we don't like, we'll still keep the ones we like to judge others for" which there is no evidence of whatsoever.

“No evidence whatsoever” is flippantly incorrect, but you can disprove the evidence, such as attempted with sacrifice prior.

> If it were true then why does Jesus rebuke people for not following the supposed "new way" pre-Atonement?

I’m not sure what you’re saying here. What “new way?”

> “The whole format of the sermon (and basically his entire ministry) for one: "You have heard it said...but I say to you do not do that, but do this instead". Almost every time he says that he's quoting an Old Testament law and condemning it.”

The quotes in question will be Matthew 5:21, 27, 31, 33, 38, and 43.

“You have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not murder; and whoever murders will be liable to judgment.’ But I say to you that everyone who is angry with his brother will be liable to judgment; whoever insults his brother will be liable to the council; and whoever says, ‘You fool!’ will be liable to the hell of fire. So if you are offering your gift at the altar and there remember that your brother has something against you, leave your gift there before the altar and go. First be reconciled to your brother, and then come and offer your gift.”

We can reason that Jesus does not wish to abolish the command “You shall not murder,” as either side of the argument contains to records of God ruling murder acceptable, nor does there exist record of God opposed to judgment for murder. Jesus does not reject that God commanded against murder, but it is in His power to evolve the command. Though it was not yet revealed in the Old Testament due to the hard hearts of man, Jesus is enforcing the command against murder to it’s roots, malice towards one’s brother. In mentioning the established command, he demonstrates the base for his enforcement on the spiritual grounds of non-love towards a fellow Man. Though the OT command allowed some flexibility in this regard, Jesus stiffened the command, as it would now be efficient in causing more good in the world as those with softer hearts can now understand. 

“You have heard that it was said, ‘You shall not commit adultery.’ But I say to you that everyone who looks at a woman with lustful intent has already committed adultery with her in his heart. If your right eye causes you to sin, tear it out and throw it away. For it is better that you lose one of your members than that your whole body be thrown into hell. And if your right hand causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. For it is better that you lose one of your members than that your whole body go into hell.”

Jesus again doesn’t disagree with the command against adultery, but it allows that outside the physical. The complete commandment against adultery, a command against lust outside the physical, at the time of the OT would be a failure of efficiency and ultimately reject the Old and New Testament concept of God using others’ choices of evil to establish good. Though it could be done with “good intentions”, God knows better than to declare a command that would only cause greater evil with no regard to the good of the future.

“It was also said, ‘Whoever divorces his wife, let him give her a certificate of divorce.’ But I say to you that everyone who divorces his wife, except on the ground of sexual immorality, makes her commit adultery, and whoever marries a divorced woman commits adultery.”

Though the original command’s allowance of divorce on the basis of indecency seems to allow flexibility, to the reason defined prior, Jesus again builds upon the command, evolving indecency to sexual immorality. 

“Again you have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not swear falsely, but shall perform to the Lord what you have sworn.’ But I say to you, Do not take an oath at all, either by heaven, for it is the throne of God, or by the earth, for it is his footstool, or by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the great King. And do not take an oath by your head, for you cannot make one hair white or black. Let what you say be simply ‘Yes’ or ‘No’; anything more than this comes from evil.”

We can copy/paste the prior interpretations here, though it would be worth noting that Jesus was, most likely, speaking in hyperbole. Rather than rebuking all solemn oaths and vows, Jesus would’ve been rebuking the misuse of God in a non-reverent nature, such as “I swear to God!”

You have heard that it was said, ‘You shall love your neighbor and hate your enemy.’ But I say to you, love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you, so that you may be sons of your Father who is in heaven. For he makes his sun rise on the evil and on the good, and sends rain on the just and on the unjust. For if you love those who love you, what reward do you have? Do not even the tax collectors do the same? And if you greet only your brothers, what more are you doing than others? Do not even the Gentiles do the same? You therefore must be perfect, as your heavenly Father is perfect.

Though the OT never said to hate your enemy, there were likely many at this time who took “neighbor” to mean ally, therefore allowing one to hate one’s enemy. Jesus concludes this section of the Sermon by giving a command to love one’s enemies.

> And the most fundamental problem is that there is ZERO evidence of God ever sanctioning "The Bible". He did not drop it out of the sky one day, and he did not ever say it was protected from error. It was put together by humans, copied over the millenia by humans, and made into a replacement for the spirit by humans. 

God dropping The Bible from the sky obviously isn’t the only way to examine it’s authenticity, and repeating "no evidence" doesn't change that. One way to examine authenticity would be to see what Jesus Himself said about the OT, which was put together by humans, and examine the NT.

(1/2)
parent.body_html:
“While the people of Israel were in the wilderness, they found a man gathering sticks on the Sabbath day. And those who found him gathering sticks brought him to Moses and Aaron and to all the congregation. They put him in custody, because it had not been made clear what should be done to him. And the Lord said to Moses, “The man shall be put to death; all the congregation shall stone him with stones outside the camp.” And all the congregation brought him outside the camp and stoned him to death with stones, as the Lord commanded Moses.”

The death penalty for violating the sabbath was originally set in Exodus 31:14, “You shall keep the Sabbath, because it is holy for you. Everyone who profanes it shall be put to death. Whoever does any work on it, that soul shall be cut off from among his people.”

Granted, this could be what led the Pharisees into condemning picking up any item on the sabbath. However, the command for the Sabbath was not to work, and we can logically assume:

  1. The man was not gathering sticks for no reason.
  2. The man was not gathering sticks to prepare an offering, which is permitted in Numbers 28:9, and confirmed by Jesus in Matthew 12, and would ironically be considered to “profane” the sabbath by the Pharisees(“Or have you not read in the Law how on the Sabbath the priests in the temple profane the Sabbath and are guiltless?”)

The most rational conclusion would be that this man was gathering sticks in a work effort involving sticks, thereby deserving of his penalty. However, “work” does not mean getting out of bed in the morning, nor does it mean lifting up food to eat, such as Jesus were.

"Man was not made for the Sabbath, but the Sabbath for man". This alone is a major contradiction.

No? It’s a plainly true statement. Jesus acknowledges that Man was created, then the Sabbath was created as a day to cease working, in remembrance of God ceasing the creation of the universe on the seventh day. This is contradictory to the Pharisees’ idea that Man cannot be healed on the Sabbath, despite it not being work. It’s only a “major contradiction” if you distort the idea of the Sabbath.

The Pharisees were following the prescription just as it was written in their time. No. We see, by the Matthew 12 example, that they followed a misinterpretation of the sabbath.

When you try to reconcile so many contradicting ideas you end up with things like Marcionism, or like most of modern Christendom picking and choosing the parts that align with the preferred theology and ignoring those that don't.

When you try to reconcile all contradictory ideas, it would end up with things like Marcionism. If we instead review each idea and it’s individual merit, while accepting that, upon review, most interpretations simply don’t hold water, such as God condemning animal sacrifice, we do not end up with things like Marcionism. If we were to have two historical accounts, John entered the code 3815 to the safe at 11:00 pm. It opened. He closed it. John entered the code 2815 to the safe at 11:03 pm. It didn’t open.

Interpretations: “It was the wrong code.” “The safe is racist.” “The first historical account is fake.” “The safe isn’t real.” “They are different Johns”

If I were to say, “Alright, the safe is a racist and nonexistant. The first account is fake, and between the first and second account are different Johns. Also, it was the wrong code,” I wouldn’t be taken seriously. If I were to say, “Alright, the safe can’t be racist and nonexistant at the same time, the first historical account is fake,” I could be taken even less seriously. With the information we have, we can say “It was the wrong code,” is the interpretation we should follow.

The typical excuse for doing this is called dispensationalism, where Jesus apparently "fulfilled the law, well at least the parts we don't like, we'll still keep the ones we like to judge others for" which there is no evidence of whatsoever.

“No evidence whatsoever” is flippantly incorrect, but you can disprove the evidence, such as attempted with sacrifice prior.

If it were true then why does Jesus rebuke people for not following the supposed "new way" pre-Atonement?

I’m not sure what you’re saying here. What “new way?”

“The whole format of the sermon (and basically his entire ministry) for one: "You have heard it said...but I say to you do not do that, but do this instead". Almost every time he says that he's quoting an Old Testament law and condemning it.”

body:
> The Bible was written far prior to the compilation of the church. Unless you can prove the Church tampered with the already created Bible, the idea that the church wanted to counter obvious heresies adds nothing to the argument.

Some of the books are authentic, some are not. Some of the authentic ones are given far higher priority than they should be. And yes the church tampered with it to promote their agenda and reign in the original Christian movement. Especially the epistles of Paul. There is very clear evidence of it if you're willing to look. The Jewish priesthood tampered with the Old Testament the exact same way. Organized religion is a scam.

And if the Bible is so authoritative, then why did God wait until a couple hundred years ago to reveal it?

As for sacrifices, why does the Psalm author say he would bring a sacrifice if God had pleasure in it? Yet the Torah specifically requires a sacrifice as atonement for sin, and claims it pleases God because of a "savory aroma". Every other place God looks favorably on sacrifice is as a thank you, like a Lent type thing, as you admit that he condemns it for other reasons. Yet the Torah also prescribes it for exactly those reasons. And Christianity did away with them altogether, which matches the complaint in Jeremiah 7. Islam recognizes this but they just use it as an excuse to replace it with their own book that is also no different other than because they say so. Everyone claims their own book is special even though it's not.

The Bible was written far prior to the compilation of the church. Unless you can prove the Church tampered with the already created Bible, the idea that the church wanted to counter obvious heresies adds nothing to the argument.

Some of the books are authentic, some are not. Some of the authentic ones are given far higher priority than they should be. And yes the church tampered with it to promote their agenda and reign in the original Christian movement. Especially the epistles of Paul. There is very clear evidence of it if you're willing to look. The Jewish priesthood tampered with the Old Testament the exact same way. Organized religion is a scam.

And if the Bible is so authoritative, then why did God wait until a couple hundred years ago to reveal it?

As for sacrifices, why does the Psalm author say he would bring a sacrifice if God had pleasure in it? Yet the Torah specifically requires a sacrifice as atonement for sin, and claims it pleases God because of a "savory aroma". Every other place God looks favorably on sacrifice is as a thank you, like a Lent type thing, as you admit that he condemns it for other reasons. Yet the Torah also prescribes it for exactly those reasons. And Christianity did away with them altogether, which matches the complaint in Jeremiah 7. Islam recognizes this but they just use it as an excuse to replace it with their own book that is also no different other than because they say so. Everyone claims their own book is special even though it's not.

parent.body:
> Not because God told them to, but because Marcion did it, and they wanted to have a counter-canon. Jesus could not have even read "The Bible" because it didn't exist until the Roman church compiled it 3 and 1/2 centuries later.

The Bible was written far prior to the compilation of the church. Unless you can prove the Church tampered with the already created Bible, the idea that the church wanted to counter obvious heresies adds nothing to the argument.

> Even after this "The Bible" in its modern form, as you know it today, would not exist until after the Reformation! 

Creating a translation of the Bible doesn’t cause it's original date to move.

> You only believe so because other people told you so.

I believe the Bible has authority because it has rationally proved itself as such, and other people believing the same isn’t going to make me run away from the conclusion, as though I must be the Select and all others must be wrong. 

Isaiah 50, verses in question:
“Hear, O my people, and I will speak;
O Israel, I will testify against you.
I am God, your God.
Not for your sacrifices do I rebuke you;
your burnt offerings are continually before me.
I will not accept a bull from your house
or goats from your folds.
For every beast of the forest is mine,
the cattle on a thousand hills.
I know all the birds of the hills,
and all that moves in the field is mine.
“If I were hungry, I would not tell you,
for the world and its fullness are mine.
Do I eat the flesh of bulls
or drink the blood of goats?
Offer to God a sacrifice of thanksgiving,
and perform your vows to the Most High,
and call upon me in the day of trouble;
I will deliver you, and you shall glorify me.
But to the wicked God says:
“What right have you to recite my statutes
or take my covenant on your lips?
For you hate discipline,
and you cast my words behind you.
If you see a thief, you are pleased with him,
and you keep company with adulterers.

God begins by noting that he is not giving a rebuke for lack of sacrifice. As said prior, “In every instance of God condemning animal sacrifice, without exception, his people are ignoring God’s commands and utilizing sacrifice as a mere ceremonial, ritual obedience.” Again, a nation completely forgets the true meaning of sacrifice to God. God does not eat or drink sacrifice, nor does he need it to gain ownership of livestock. Sacrifice is both a preparation of the path to Jesus, and as God is pleased with us asking for forgiveness today, sacrifice was a method to repent when one fails God’s commands. However, God announces that those who are continually wicked have no right to “recite my statutes,” as with literally every single example of God “condemning” sacrifice, they were ignoring God’s moral commands.

Even after this "The Bible" in its modern form, as you know it today, would not exist until after the Reformation!

Creating a translation of the Bible doesn’t cause it's original date to move.

body: Romans 7 is an allusion to a Jewish law that just so happens to regard marriage. The 10 virgins is about preparation. None of these match the "Christ is married to the church" thing, it's a big book and such a common thing in life is bound to appear more than once. The Ephesians one was just made up to get Christians back in line. This passage in particular serves two goals to convince Christians of doing: first to forsake celibacy and have more babies, and secondly to comply with the established gender roles. Ephesians reads like a church-sanitized summary of Paul's letters, and doesn't fit his writing style upon inspection and is at many points inconsistent with Paul. Even if it was authentic, Ephesians has been extensively edited, to the point where even the recipient has been changed (it used to be Laodecians).

I don't necessarily disagree with this text but I can still feel his attitude in it.

body: Marriage is probably *the* most common human institution. Of course it's going to pop up from the time to time. The mere mention of it does not equate to there being a literal mystery as Ephesians insists and that we are to replicate it. It was created for humans and it dies with humans, that's what Jesus flat out said. There is a serious problem with taking every metaphor as literally as possible.

body: It doesn't exist. Anyone familiar with the history of the time period when the Bible was composed will know this. The closest thing we have to a hell from early times is that some universalists believed in a purgatorial hell. Rome (shockingly) was the first to make up hell and it was a very valuable tool to control people. Protestants later did away with purgatory but not hell because they read their pre-existing Catholic notions into the text. Even this article admits they use hell to scare people into listening to them and that's why they're worried about it being exposed. So it's no surprise that their "support" is almost all theologians from the past couple centuries. I've been duped myself by several false teachers by the "if you don't listen to me you're going to hell!" message, it's an effective strategy.

parent.body:
Everyone goes through a rebellious phase. But ultimately, the Holy Spirit itself is not an isolationist enlightenment, it's depicted as a social one. It's the glue that makes the Kingdom of God possible. Under any orthodox interpretation of Christianity it is simply not possible to be an individualist unit of worship.

A lot of Gnostic movements believed you could do that, and almost as soon as the last Gnostic resurgence died, the Reformation (particularly Calvin) brought back most of the same principles under a more traditionalist cosmology. But that's not Christianity in any useful sense. If anything, it's more compatible with Islam.

You should take it that way. But that invalidates your previous argument that genders exist for that reason. Metaphors allude to real things, not the other way around.

The Ephesians one also does treat it as a literal truth. It calls it a "mystery" between Christ and the church; it is not a metaphor like the others because it is making this up as its excuse to make people fulfill social obligations which they otherwise would've abandoned. You would not get this impression from the other mentions of marriage at all if it weren't for this paragraph; you are reading your notions from Ephesians into them.

post.body:
> In an open letter to all Catholics, Pope Leo XIII addressed the conditions of the working classes, the relationships between labor and capital, as well as government and its citizens. The letter supported the rights of labor to form unions, rejected socialism as well as unrestricted capitalism, while affirming the right to private property.

> Pope Leo XIII also maintained that the role of government is to promote social justice through the protection of rights, while the Church must work to teach correct social principles and ensure class harmony. He restated the Church's long-standing teaching regarding the crucial importance of private property rights, but recognized that the free operation of market forces must be tempered by moral considerations.

[Site That has PDF Download Link Of Text (And The Description Above)](https://digitalcommons.providence.edu/catholic_documents/13/)

[Catholic Encyclopedia Entry On Topic](https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/12783a.htm)

[Infogalactic Entry On Topic](https://infogalactic.com/info/Rerum_novarum)
post.body_html:
In an open letter to all Catholics, Pope Leo XIII addressed the conditions of the working classes, the relationships between labor and capital, as well as government and its citizens. The letter supported the rights of labor to form unions, rejected socialism as well as unrestricted capitalism, while affirming the right to private property.

Pope Leo XIII also maintained that the role of government is to promote social justice through the protection of rights, while the Church must work to teach correct social principles and ensure class harmony. He restated the Church's long-standing teaching regarding the crucial importance of private property rights, but recognized that the free operation of market forces must be tempered by moral considerations.

Site That has PDF Download Link Of Text (And The Description Above)

Catholic Encyclopedia Entry On Topic

Infogalactic Entry On Topic

body:
I make similar claims to Islam because Islam recognizes them as true. Yet Islam twists it into an excuse to make up their own religion and book and calls *that* absolute truth instead.

Early Christians met in house churches. While pagans made sacrifices for favors from "the gods" and worshiped with rituals and idols. And they controlled the whole empire and persecuted those who refused to worship the Roman gods. The organized priesthood of the Old Testament pushed the same crap. It's funny, they actually condemn not only several Hebrew patriarchs and their associates but also *Jesus himself* because his lineage is Samaritan, not "pure Israelite" or whatever. According to them he is inherently evil, a half goy and therefore only half human, cannot hold office, probably not even worthy enough to enter the temple, and not being a Levite, should be stoned if he dares even approach priestly materials.

It makes no sense for polytheism to suddenly engulf people. It does make sense for monotheism to become corrupted into polytheism over the generations.

And yes a major redaction of both testaments did happen. It was not always devious, because that was considered appropriate and often beneficial in ancient times, but it did happen. We don't have any manuscript evidence because our manuscripts don't go back that far, possibly even because unorthodox ones were destroyed by the church. We also don't have any manuscript evidence of the Gospel of the Lord or the Gospel of the Hebrews for example, but we know they existed because church fathers quote them.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

parent.body:
That's not true, and it shows that you haven't done your research on either Old or New Testament sources. The Priestly history of ancient Israel is the most normative, by far. The Deuteronomist source is where the extravagant myths come from. Your claim is not born out by historical reality at all. Not even a little.

The entire point of religion in the first place is to organize a tribe's morality. If you aren't an "organized" Christian, you aren't a Christian. You aren't a part of our tradition and you share no part in our values. You don't have the holy spirit, which is an expressly communal entity. You're just stealing our name and making us look bad.

You also keep referencing a redaction of the New Testament that didn't actually happen to the degree that you seem to think it did. Or at least, there's no evidence if it did. You have a bad habit of pulling these kinds of falsehoods out of thin air.

Disorganized religion, where it has historically existed (almost never) was always pagan until Calvin's era of the Reformation. It's a brand new idea, not one shared by Christ, Scripture, or Tradition. But you don't seem to hold any of those authoritative anyway, which raises the question; why do you even consider yourself a Christian rather than a faith that's actually compatible with your ideas? You don't abide by any prerequisites to any useful form of Christianity. Your truth claims are distinctly reminiscent of Islam.

post.body:
> In an open letter to all Catholics, Pope Leo XIII addressed the conditions of the working classes, the relationships between labor and capital, as well as government and its citizens. The letter supported the rights of labor to form unions, rejected socialism as well as unrestricted capitalism, while affirming the right to private property.

> Pope Leo XIII also maintained that the role of government is to promote social justice through the protection of rights, while the Church must work to teach correct social principles and ensure class harmony. He restated the Church's long-standing teaching regarding the crucial importance of private property rights, but recognized that the free operation of market forces must be tempered by moral considerations.

[Site That has PDF Download Link Of Text (And The Description Above)](https://digitalcommons.providence.edu/catholic_documents/13/)

[Catholic Encyclopedia Entry On Topic](https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/12783a.htm)

[Infogalactic Entry On Topic](https://infogalactic.com/info/Rerum_novarum)
post.body_html:
In an open letter to all Catholics, Pope Leo XIII addressed the conditions of the working classes, the relationships between labor and capital, as well as government and its citizens. The letter supported the rights of labor to form unions, rejected socialism as well as unrestricted capitalism, while affirming the right to private property.

Pope Leo XIII also maintained that the role of government is to promote social justice through the protection of rights, while the Church must work to teach correct social principles and ensure class harmony. He restated the Church's long-standing teaching regarding the crucial importance of private property rights, but recognized that the free operation of market forces must be tempered by moral considerations.
